sn2.8:4.2: Then, late at night, the beautiful god Tāyana, formerly a religious founder, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha,
sn2.8:4.4: and recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:
sn2.8:5.3: A sage who doesn’t give up sensual pleasures
sn2.8:5.4: is not reborn in a unified state.
sn2.8:6.1: If one is to do what should be done,
sn2.8:6.3: For the life gone forth when laxly led
sn2.8:6.4: just stirs up dust all the more.
sn2.8:7.1: It’s better to leave a bad deed undone—
sn2.8:7.2: later you burn for that misdeed.
sn2.8:7.3: It’s better to have done a good deed,
sn2.8:7.4: after doing which you don’t burn up.
sn2.8:8.1: When kusa grass is wrongly grasped
sn2.8:8.3: So too, the ascetic life, when wrongly taken,
sn2.8:10.1: That’s what the god Tāyana said.
sn2.8:10.2: Then he bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right side, before vanishing right there.
sn2.8:11.1: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.
sn2.8:11.2: “Mendicants, tonight, the beautiful god Tāyana, formerly a religious founder, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, came to me,
sn2.8:11.4: and recited these verses in my presence.” The Buddha repeated the verses in full, adding:
sn2.8:17.1: That’s what the god Tāyana said. Then he bowed and respectfully circled me, keeping me on his right side, before vanishing right there.
sn2.8:17.2: Mendicants, learn the verses of Tāyana!
sn2.8:17.5: These verses are beneficial and relate to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”
